p: Our research has limitations. Standards of surveillance and reporting of HPAI H5N1 cases vary by country and locality, potentially introducing sampling bias [25], [26]. Also, given the higher occurrence of infection with H5N1 in poultry in the winter, surveillance may be more rigorous in these high-risk months. Case reports in the literature were of inconsistent quality and almost never followed standardized reporting guidelines such as the WHO Clinical Case Summary Form [27]. Since we were interested in the illness onset of human cases, and only sporadic clusters of limited, non-sustained human-to-human transmission have occurred to date, we did not distinguish between transmission modality (zoonotic or human-to-human).
